Posts.Content: nanc512 wrote: My results are in. She wrote it out for me on a referral to see a surgeon tomorrow. She said it is invasive ductal breast cancer. Since the area is so large and there are two, she feels like a mastectomy would be best. She also said I would most likely have radiation and chemo. My mind is a fog, I am trying to figure out everything I need to take care of because she talked to the surgeon herself and he said he would fit me in the next OR opening to get this over with. I won't know until tomorrow if he thinks a lumpectomy or mastectomy is the way to go. I feel like a mastectomy is best, get it all. Anything I should know before I see the surgeon tomorrow? He comes highly recommended, so I feel I am in good hands. Several ladies from church have had him as their surgeon. Thanks. Nancy Dx 6/23/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 08:54PM nanc512 wrote: Hello: I am starting chemo next week.  I have to call tomorrow to see what he decided and see if I agree.  lol  I had a lumpectomy and SNB in early July.  Preliminary showed SN was okay, final came back as microscopic.  I needed a re-excision, but after many conferences and an MRI, we decided the area was too large.  I had a mastectomy on 8/20, power port in and lymph nodes out.  I have had lots of complications, including dehydration, blood loss, drain problems and now a seroma.  But, I am feeling much better and ready to face this chemo head on. He is either doing AC and then T, or TAC.  I am not sure what the advantage would be to having them all at once.  I thought the AC and T would be 4 treatments each, every 2 weeks.  The TAC I thought is 6 treatments every 3 weeks.  I was sure he said something about taking time off by doing the TAC.  I will find out tomorrow. I didn't get anti-nausea meds to take ahead of time, so that's on my list.  I am going wig shopping this weekend and will talk to him about a script and see if insurance will pay for it. Did I miss anything?  Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 09:40PM - edited Oct 4, 2007 09:40PM by nanc512 I saw the NP today.  My white count is .9, so I am laying low.  She gave me a script for Emend.  My insurance would only pay $90 on it, so I had to pay $207 for three pills.  She also gave me a script for Decadron.  I am supposed to bring all of them to chemo next week and will start taking them there. My frustration is mounting, this has taken over my life and I wonder if I have allowed it?  I forgot to ask her the time frame on the Neulesta building back up my WBC.  I have a huge family thing Saturday night and I hope none of them are sick! Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 02:50PM - edited Oct 7, 2007 02:50PM by nanc512 Hi fellow September chemo buddies: My fever finally broke, so I snuck out to the store early today when there were few people around.  I am doing the stomach thing like many of you, rumbling, diarrhea, etc...  My newest problem is all my mucous membranes drying out; eyes, mouth and female area.  My friend brought me some Replens and it is helping, but I need to use it daily.  Someone told me to get KY Liquid Beads, so I might do that later today.  I am just afraid to go out since my wbc was so low and I have been running a fever. I don't drink much diet pepsi anymore, just doesn't taste good.  I am have been drinking water and it's tasting good so far.  Some of my favorite foods taste awful.  I do love baked potatoes and mac/cheese, both of those taste good. I have continually lost weight, intentionally, and keep dropping a few pounds each week.  I start Emend/Decadron next week, I paid $207 for 3 Emend pills!  I need to ask my doc if he can get samples.  I am wondering when the weight gain will begin........ugh Blessings to all of you! Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 05:42PM nanc512 wrote: I start chemo next Thursday, they are doing AC x 4, every 2 weeks followed by Taxotere x 4 every 2 weeks.  I need to research about Taxotere, I have heard about Taxol.  I am planning on wearing tops that will allow easy access to my port.   I am going to bring a book and a bottle of water, figure I will be thirsty after being there.  She said to count on two hours.   The nurse assured me they will help me work through any side effects the best they can.  She said I will need to go back 24 hours later (they try to make it real close to 24 hours) for my Neulasta injection.  I am really trying to go into this with an open mind and not focus on side effects.  The nurse said Emend (?) is very expensive and insurance doesn't always like to pay for it, so I will get two meds in my IV and then they have samples for me to take home.  She said I need to communicate with them on every side effect and how I felt, they encourage patients to keep a journal.  She said to call and let them know so they can adjust meds or replace them. I have some stool softener I got before my surgeries and I was glad I had it on hand.  I will make sure I have flavored water, saltines and other stuff easy on my stomach.  I have read that people really crave certain foods and some foods are a complete turn off. My friend will be buzzing my hair when it starts to come out.  I think I will get some caps and scarves too.  I know I want a sleep cap.  It will be hard on my elderly mom and my son too see me with no hair.  It's going to be reality, but I want to make it easy on them.  Mom has macular degeneration, lives with me and doesn't drive.  My son is 19 and has a connective tissue disease and deals with significant visual impairment and joint problems.  I am the only driver, but I have a great group of friends and church members to help me! I love how we can support each other as we begin this segment of our journey in September. Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 04:44PM nanc512 wrote: My first chemo is Thursday and I am getting anxious.  I have been making my list to go shopping tomorrow.  I am doing 4 AC treatments every two weeks, followed by 4 Taxotere treatments every two weeks. I have my wig, ordered a few caps and scarves.  I work at home, so I can wear the same thing and not worry about it.  I am hoping to continue to work since I can rest and spread my work throughout the day.  I am wondering if the doctors' theory that any side effects we have with the first treatment will kind of predict the following treatments. I see the nurse practitioner for my chemo Thursday and I have a list of questions for her.  I get sinus headaches frequently this time of year, so I need to find out what I can take.  I am packing my chemo bag with a book, crackers, water and some ribbon headbands to work on while I am there.  The nurse said to count on two hours.  Then I go back the next day for the Neulesta shot.  My elderly mom is worried that I should have someone go with me, she doesn't drive.  I decided that books and tv shows don't depict chemo the way it is in real life.  People keep telling me attitude is a huge portion of the recover process.  I am confident I will beat this and am going to do my best to minimize the side effects! God bless all of you, He has blessed me. Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 04:22PM nanc512 wrote: I love hearing the stories.  Tri and I are going to be chemo twins, starting on the same day, the same protocol for the first four treatments!  I think it's great that several of you have few side effects, you are not bragging!  This gives hope for the rest of us.  I am just amazed at how taking the same medication for the same condition with some of us having the same stats affects us differently.  I am very sensitive to medication, so this is scary.  I can take very few OTC products, can't take Ambien, I took a 1 mg Ativan before my MRI and it made me so lightheaded. My surgeon and onc say I will fly through this, because I have had all my troubles the previous three months.  I had so many weird things with every procedure, every surgery.......  I am off to the store with my list, so I can be prepared. I will keep my Sept sisters updated! Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 10:34PM - edited Oct 2, 2007 10:34PM by nanc512 My first chemo was last Thursday and I ended up in the hospital for 3 days, it was awful.  I had Aloxi and Decadron before, then AC.  Within 3 hours, I was so nauseated.  I had Compazine and took it every 4 hours.  By the next morning, I couldn't do anything, but lay in bed, started vomiting, etc...  They sent me to the ER, gave me Zofran and alternated with Compazine.  They admitted me, I was dehydrated, too.  I had clear liquids for 24 hours and worked my way up to soft foods.  I was miserable and am anxious to see what they do the next time.  I haven't been that sick with nausea ever.  I am still going slow, came home Sunday night and am tired and working my way up to normal food. I got the Neulesta shot and didn't appear to have a reaction unless the nausea masked it.  I ran a fever for part of my stay, but it went away. Anything I should ask in particular on Thursday when I see my doc?  He was out of town, so I saw another onc.  My next chemo is 10/11.  I keep trying to stay positive, saying 12.5% done, but this is awful. Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 04:08PM nanc512 wrote: Sorry I haven't updated for months and months.  Chemo was really tough, I was down for most of September - February.  I am just now starting to feel better and be active. I developed neuropathy and it's pretty bad.  I went back to the onc today and got samples of Femara, they took blood to test to see if my ovaries are still active.  I still have my port, not sure when it will come out.  I fell two weeks ago and broke my finger, sprained my shoulder and got banged up.  I lost feeling in my feet and went down on my finger pads on concrete.  Anyone else taking Femara and have input? Trigeek:  I just read a bunch of messages and got caught up on my chemo twin!  I didn't realize I had private messages here too and found a bunch of people checking on me and looking for me.  I feel so bad.  I will keep in touch now that I can sit at my desk and type (even with one finger in a splint).  lol Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 10:32AM nanc512 wrote: Hey twin: My hair is very thick, but I am shedding more.  My scalp is kind of tingling, so I expect chunks to start falling.  I got really down about this last night, so I am thinking of it as the hair being associated with my cancer, so it has to go!  I am losing hair on other parts of my body. I have my wig and decided I would buy more hats and scarves, I have a few, but I don't want to wear my wig all the time.  I am going to order a fall to wear under some hats. Hopefully, I will feel like posting my update tomorrow.  I am really apprehensive about doing this again, but I have to. Nancy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: nanc512 wrote: I am just not feeling well after my mastectomy, port and lymph node removal. I had a fever in the hospital, I am on antibiotics at home and my fever is getting worse. I bought a new digital thermometer recently and it doesn't register above 98.1, but I am burning up and mom said I feel hot, not warm. Anyone else have fevers after surgery? My drains are good, incisions just give me pain every once in a while. I have horrible pain in what I think is the back of my arm. If I sit and don't move, I am okay. But moving, even the unaffected arm, will set off this stinging burning pains that will last a few minutes and then settle down to a dull pain. I am assuming that is from the lymph node removal. I knew I would be sore, but am concerned about the type of pain it is. I am wondering if it's nerve pain. I see the nurse practitioner at 1:10, she is taking the drains out. I am still draining quite a bit, so she might not take them. I am going to talk to her about Hydrocodone, it gives me a headache, so I am going to see if there is something else I can take. I decided I can't let this pain get the best of me, but I can't play tough and not say this hurts and I need something to make it feel better. I was prepared for the stomach problems yesterday, so they weren't bad. I found these store brand iced oatmeal cookies are the best relief for constipation and they work in a very short time. I keep telling myself I had major surgery on Monday and it takes time, I just wasn't prepared for the fever and this awful pain. Thanks. Nancy Dx 6/23/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 07:57PM nanc512 wrote: Paxton:  Glad to see you are feeling better.  I have AC #2 on Thursday.  I have my Emend and Decadron, so I am ready.  I just started feeling better today, I am hoping and praying this one doesn't knock me down like the last one.  The not knowing part is scary and not being able to plan. I am finding myself more emotional now.  I feel like a castoff from my friends.  They just expect me to be sick all the time, since I have had so many problems from the beginning.  I know how tired I am of this, so I don't bring anything up to them, until they ask.  I really don't think anyone can even come close to understanding until they have gone through it. Prayers being said for all my September 07 chemo buddies! Nancy

Posts.Content: nanc512 wrote: I have been trying to learn more and more before I get my results tomorrow. I am wondering what kind of time frame is involved between results and surgery, if needed. I know most of it depends on getting in to the surgeon and actual scheduling. If the findings are cancer, early stages, how soon should surgery be done? If the findings aren't conclusive and a lumpectomy is recommened, how soon should that be done. If the findings are not cancer, but the lumpectomy is recommended due to pain and discomfort, what is the time frame? I have read lots of messages and it seems the surgery doesn't have to happen right away, although I know I would want it over with. I really want to be prepared if I need to make decisions. I do trust my primary care doctor and she is very pro active and not a push over. I am so grateful for that, I know she will help get whatever, if anything, I need done. Thanks again for everyone sharing their stories, it is such a relief to gain knowledge through reading messages. My son has a rare condition and I started a group 8 years ago for families to go to for support. We have grown so much and are international, parents no longer feel alone. Nancy Dx 6/23/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Time frame for surgery nanc512 kathleenalam

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 02:54AM nanc512 wrote: I didn't have the same circumstances, but my sentinel node came back clear during surgery, final showed microscopic cancer.  I had the Axillary Lymph Dissection when I had my mastectomy.  The oncologist felt I was on the line and the surgeon said he would not take the nodes out just for staging purposes.  The three of us decided since the sentinel node was positive, more should come out.  With it being microscopic, we didn't know if the others were affected. They took 6 out and they were clean, so I won't have radiation to my axillary area now.  I am looking at my path report and it says my sentinel node was .2 cm for the max diameter.  The largest focus was 2 mm in greatest dimension. I talked extensively with my oncologist and surgeon about lymph node removal, I think I could have pushed them and not had it done, but I wanted to know if it had spread.  My situation is different from yours, because they only tested the sentinel node and there wasn't much cancer there.  I had to have the mastectomy, since the lumpectomy didn't get it all and chemo port in, so I had them take the nodes out at the same time.  It is not an easy recovery, some people said it was easy.  I have had many complications from my mastectomy and still have them, 3+ weeks out.  My lymph node area is much better now, but I have had lots of pain and soreness. I would ask them if they are doing this for staging only.  Are they doing another procedure at the same time?  I don't think I have heard of anyone having more out after taking that many the first time. Keep us updated. Nancy

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2007 09:11PM nanc512 wrote: I have two wonderful RTR mentors.  They are like sisters to me now.  One is the chief nursing officer at the hospital and she is there with me for every surgery, before and after.  She calls me a few times a week to check on me and has given me lots of neat things.  The other is a surgery nurse, she has gone through chemo, so she will be in close contact with me when I start. I haven't been as impressed with our ACS office, but we don't have a local office, it's about 2 hours away.  I have had to drag info out of them, but my RTR mentors are awesome. Nancy

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 09:47PM nanc512 wrote: Hi ladies: I had my mastectomy in August last year.  I developed a huge seroma, surgeon said it might take a year to go away.  I have no idea what it's supposed to look like, but it looks like I have a C on side and an A on the other.  I haven't been fitted for any prothesis or bras yet, because I think I should wait until the site is flatter.  Does that make sense?  I had a huge amount of swelling, much has gone away, but he said the dried blood part would take a long time.  I am done with chemo (thank goodness) and am thinking about swimming.  I have no clue what to do.  I guess I need a suit, but I want something modest, I am down to a size 18 finally. Any good places I should look?  I guess I can use a shower puffy until I get a prothesis.  I have been using the puffy foam things I got with my surgery camisoles.  For a long time I did nothing, just decided to use one and look semi-equal.  :-) Thanks. Nancy
Posts.Title: Bathing suit came today caaclark Erica

Posts.Content: nanc512 wrote: I have had a lump for sometime, but it seemed to come and go. Last week it got very painful and tender, it's on the inside lower part and only in one breast. At the same time I became really sick with headache, sore throat, very tired and just blah. I went to the walk in clinic a week ago and he managed to get my appt moved up with my doctor, I had made one about the lump, but had to wait two weeks. He did a chest xray and blood work, thinking I had pneumonia. He came back and said I had a bad bacterial infection and my neutrophils were high. I was put on Cephalexin 500 mg, 4 per day. By the second day the breast pain was gone and the tenderness was minimal. I saw my doctor this past Tuesday, she said the lump is solid and movable. She sent me for an immediate diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. She ordered the fine needle aspiration if the other tests called for it. I went back on Thursday for the FNA. The radiologist said they found another small spot on the mammogram, so they biopsied both. I am 49 and very worried, no history of breast cancer in my family. My doctor did say she would most likely recommend a lumpectomy. I really thought it was a cyst or abscess because the pain and tenderness went away with antiobiotics. I think it's smaller now. It also appears to have moved since the FNA. Today I have a long narrow blister above the incision, no pain with it and it doesn't appear infected. My doctor goes to my church and said she would check on me tomorrow, so I am going to ask about the blister. I didn't feel a trip to the ER was warranted, since there is no redness and it doesn't appear infected. I wonder if they used clamps during the FNA. I couldn't see that well. The waiting game is so difficult. I know no one has the answers, but am glad to find a community that understands. The resident I saw for the pre-exam thought it was unusual for the lump to be on the inside. Any suggestions on what I should do in the meantime? Any words of wisdom? Thanks. Nancy Dx 6/23/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
